Description: This elaborate, enameled plaque was once attached to the cover of a Gospel book or a lectionary, a manuscript containing passages from the four Gospels arranged to be read throughout the year. At the center, Christ is flanked by the Virgin and St. John. Adam's skull, below, symbolizes the salvation of mankind through Christ's crucifixion on Golgotha, the reputed site of Adam's grave.

Exhibitions.Textblock: The History of Bookbinding 525-1950 A.D.. Baltimore Museum of Art, Baltimore. 1957-1958.
Illuminated Manuscripts: Masterpieces in Miniature. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1984-1985.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Songs of Glory: Medieval Art from 900-1500
Exhibitions.Textblock: Songs of Glory: Medieval Art from 900-1500. Oklahoma Museum of Art, Oklahoma City. 1985.

Inscriptions: Text in gilded copper on cross above Christ's head: I H S/ X P~S; [Transcription] IH[ESU]S CHR[ISTU]S; [Translation] Jesus Christ.  In this inscription, the titulus (the long horizontal mark indicating an abbreviation) has an unusual placement between the P and the S to abbreviate the initials XPS for Christ.
Medium: champlevé enamel on copper with gilding and gem stones

MuseumLocation.DisplayCurrentLocation: Centre Street: Third Floor: Romanesque and Gothic Art

Title: Book Cover Plaque
